doc.title: Event Calendar
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/European Morning Credit Today in European CreditEuropean Morning Credit Today in European Credit_2025-08-29

passages.text: Credit Strategy - Europe: Macro trading has been leading the way, in the liquidity front. CDS indices, CDS index options and credit ETFs have all benefited notably in H1 this year despite higher market volatility. However, rather surprisingly, bond market liquidity metrics have also improved, despite more frequent fragility shocks. See: Credit market liquidity - who wants to live forever? (IA)

Helaba (HESLAN): 1H was decent - see our separate note. Pre- tax profit up \(11\%\) yoy as less predictable fair- value result doubles, and lower mandatory levies. Upgraded \(4.5\%\) T2 to MW. NPLs plateau at a notable \(3.1\%\) and impairments remain contained. Some CRE deleveraging, but in the higher- rated parts. Capital buffer eerily large \((7\%\) of RWA) as Basel IV boosts the CET1 ratio to \(16.3\%\) \((+2.1\) ppts YTD). Acquisitions ahead? (LG)

UK Banks: an Institute for Public Policy Research report argues for a new levy on UK banks' Bank of England reserves, which grew because of quantitative easing, sparking new fears of rising taxes for the sector, according to the FT and Bloomberg this morning. The discussion comes in the context of the upcoming autumn budget. Details of implementation are unclear at this stage (whether through cutting remuneration on reserves, a windfall tax or an increase in the existing bank income tax surcharge). We believe the impacts on bank profitability are unlikely to be sufficiently large to materially dent the bank's credit stories. Yet uncertainty on the profit outlook will be unhelpful for the sector. See running rings around. (RT/LG)

UniCredit (UCGIM): UniCredit raised its stake in Alpha Bank by \(- 5\%\) to \(- 26\%\) yesterday (worth around 2.1bn as of yesterday close), which should have a negative 65bps impact on its CET1 ratio. The holding will generate a profit of c. 244mn for UniCredit next year. By contrast to investments in Banco BPM and Commerzbank, UniCredit's stake in Alpha Bank has generally been welcomed by political authorities. The increased stake highlights UniCredit's optionality to raise its investment further. While unlikely at this stage, a further increase could support Alpha spreads. Alpha's fundamentals have materially strengthened but in our view remain a step below domestic peers', in particular on profitability and impaired loan coverage. We have MW recommendations at best on Alpha Bank as we see better value elsewhere in the Greek complex. (RT/LG)
Orsted (ORSTED): S&P affirmed its 'BBB-' rating and maintained its stable outlook. See below for more details. (PV)

Pernod Ricard (RIFP): FY25 org. sales/EBIT growth \((- 3.0\%) / - 0.8\%\) ) better than feared (cons \(- 3.2\% / - 3\%\) ) with c. \(2\%\) beat on EBIT. Weaker profitability drives net leverage to 3.3x despite strong FCF generation. Better than expected progress on asset disposals could alleviate near- term Baa1/BBB+ rating pressure. See: Better than expected but still challenging (CF)

BofA Securities does and seeks to do business with issuers covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. Refer to important disclosures on page 7 to 12. Analyst Certification on page 6. Valuation & Risk on page 4.
European Credit Rsch Grp BofASE (France) See Team Page for List of Analysts
Exhibit 1: Just published Recent publications from European Credit Research
Credit Strategy - Europe Credit market liquidity - who wants to live forever? Ioannis Angelakis Pernod Ricard Better than expected but still challenging Conor Forde
Source: BofA Global Research
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

S&P affirmed its 'BBB-' rating and maintained its stable outlook. S&P highlights that the planned DKK60bn equity raise creates some rating headroom and the company can sustain three to six months of project halt (on Revolution Wind) before any negative impact on credit ratings. However, the agency notes that its view of Orsted's business has weakened further after the stop order.

S&P notes that it could downgrade the credit ratings if: i) stop- order on Revolution Wind exceeds the three- to- six months period, ii) Sunrise Wind receives a similar stop order, iii) project cancellation of either Revolution Wind or Sunrise Wind, iv) failure to divest Hornsea 3 (UK project) by \(50\%\) by end of 2025 or the farm- down happened under terms that S&P deems unfavourable to Orsted, and iv) likelihood of government support diminished. For i) to iii) S&P notes that remedial actions taken by Orsted can prevent a ratings downgrade.

Separately, Moody's commented that the stop- work order imposed on Revolution Wind is credit negative, as it creates uncertainty with regards to project completion. According to Moody's, the worst case scenario of Revolution Wind project cancellation is likely manageable for Orsted. But it clearly highlights the geopolitical risks in Orsted's US portfolio. Moody's continues to opine that the stop- work order will eventually be revoked, and the Revolution Wind project will be completed.

In their base case, Moody's assumes no more than one- two month delay to the Revolution Wind project and that the Sunrise Wind project will not be under the scrutiny of the US govt (BOEM - Bureau of Ocean Energy Management) at a later stage. We turned bearish on the name following the stop- work order on Revolution Wind. See Every Revolution has a foe for details. (PV)

Alpha Bank has made strong progress in reducing impaired loans, yet they are higher than Greek peers. Problem assets (impaired and foreclosed) are comparable to Piraeus.Partly as a result of rapid deleveraging in 2021, Alpha's coverage screens lower than
peers. Capital buffers are towards the higher end of peers, partly thanks to the sale of a \(90\%\) stake in the Romanian subsidiary to UniCredit. We see limited further MREL needs by 1 Jan 26.
In senior preferred, we prefer other domestic alternatives on valuation and fundamentals. We are UW the shorter- dated \(7.5\%\) and \(2.5\%\) and MW the \(6.875\%\) which screens fair.
Upside risks: a convincing increase in coverage levels which reduces tail risks to a now restored profitability, an acceleration in NPE sales, a track record of improved profitability.

Downside risks: negative surprises on impairments, which could be the result of a below- peers coverage ratio. An inability to continue reducing the stock of impaired loans could slow credit momentum more than the market has been anticipating to date.

Alpha Bank has made strong progress in reducing impaired loans, yet they are higher than Greek peers. Problem assets (impaired and foreclosed) are comparable to Piraeus. Partly as a result of rapid deleveraging in 2021, Alpha's coverage screens lower than peers. Capital buffers are towards the higher end of peers, partly thanks to the sale of a \(90\%\) stake in the Romanian subsidiary to UniCredit. We see limited further MREL needs by 1 Jan 26.
In Tier 2, we believe the \(6\%\) is overvalued as it trades too close to fundamentally stronger domestic peers. Valuation on the shorter- dated \(5.5\%\) seems fair.
Upside risks: a convincing increase in coverage levels which reduces tail risks to a now restored profitability, an acceleration in NPE sales, a track record of improved profitability.

Downside risks: negative surprises on impairments, which could be the result of a below- peers coverage ratio. An inability to continue reducing the stock of impaired loans could slow credit momentum more than the market has been anticipating to date.

Helaba is a German universal bank operating as a Landesbank mainly across the states of Hesse, Thuringia, North Rhine- Westphalia and Brandenburg. It is part of a nationwide institutional protection scheme with the broader national savings banks, which reduces funding costs as excess liquidity at the savings banks can be reinvested by retail clients in Helaba certificates. It also reduces tail risks.

But Helaba has a meaningful concentration in commercial real estate (CRE), about \(4x\) its CET1 capital. Its US CRE and office exposure each account for the third- largest in the sector, as a proportion of CET1 capital (c. \(1x\) , \(2x\) respectively). NPLs have risen sharply and are currently concentrated in Germany.

Helaba's senior spreads are tight vs similarly- rated peers despite these risks. Asset quality deterioration cannot be ruled out, even if NPLs and impairments looked steady in 1H25. We believe that interest margins will likely be lower, eroding profit cushions, while impairments could remain high. We are UW on the '27, '29, '30 seniors and MW the \(4.5\%\) and \(5.375\%\) T2s which look fair.

Upside risks: stabilising credit quality in commercial real estate, more resilient profitability than expected despite likely weaker margins and high impairments, a material reduction in non- performing loans.
Downside risks: further increases in impaired loans (e.g., linked to US commercial estate or office exposures), persistently high impairments, a rapidly deteriorating interest margin.

We recommend Underweight on €'28s, €'29s, €'33s, €'35s, €'27s, €'32s, £'34s, €'NC27s, €'NC28s, €'NC29s, €'NC30s and €'NC32s, reflecting increased policy uncertainty in the US and the stop- work order on Revolution Wind that increases costs. Credit rating agencies might wait for more clarity before taking any negative action. We are Marketweight on €'26s, reflecting the nearing maturity of the bonds.

Upside risks - faster deployment of new capacities, higher disposal proceeds from farm- downs, significant reversal of impairments, lower interest rates, supportive US government policyDownside risks - significant project delays, cancellation costs and impairments, significant issues with Sunrise Wind and Revolution Wind project, challenges with implementing asset divestment (farm- downs)

This report may contain a trading idea or recommendation which highlights a specific identified near- term catalyst or event impacting a security, issuer, industry sector or the market generally that presents a transaction opportunity, but does not have any impact on the analyst's particular "Overweight" or "Underweight" rating (which is based on a three month trade horizon). Trading ideas and recommendations may differ directionally from the analyst's rating on a security or issuer because they reflect the impact of a near- term catalyst or event.
